greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array: T(d,n) = number of ways of writing n as a sum of d squares, read along diagonals.
comment: This is the transpose of the array in A286815.
T(d,n) is divisible by 2d for any n != 0 iff d is a power of 2. - _Jianing Song_, Sep 05 2018
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals d = 1..141, flattened
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
example: Array T(d,n) with rows d = 1,2,3... and columns n = 0,1,2,3.. reads
maple: A122141 := proc(d,n) local i,cnts ; cnts := 0 ; for i from -trunc(sqrt(n)) to trunc(sqrt(n)) do if n-i^2 >= 0 then if d > 1 then cnts := cnts+procname(d-1,n-i^2) ; elif n-i^2 = 0 then cnts := cnts+1 ; fi ; fi ; od ; cnts ;
for diag from 1 to 14 do for n from 0 to diag-1 do d := diag-n ; printf("%d,",A122141(d,n)) ; od ; od;
A:= proc(d, n) option remember; `if`(n=0, 1, `if`(n<0 or d<1, 0,
seq(seq(A(h-n, n), n=0..h-1), h=1..14); # _Alois P. Heinz_, Jul 16 2014
mathematica: Table[ SquaresR[d - n, n], {d, 1, 12}, {n, 0, d - 1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 13 2013 *)

A[d_, n_] := A[d, n] = If[n==0, 1, If[n<0 || d<1, 0, A[d-1, n] + 2*Sum[A[d-1, n-j^2], {j, 1, Sqrt[n]}]]]; Table[A[h-n, n], {h, 1, 14}, {n, 0, h-1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 28 2018, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
xref: Cf. A005843 (2nd column), A046092 (3rd column), A130809 (4th column).
Cf. A010052 (1st row divides 2), A002654 (2nd row divides 4), A046897 (4th row divides 8), A008457 (8th row divides 16), A302855 (16th row divides 32), A302857 (32nd row divides 64).
results.author: _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 29 2006
